bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William Crawford Gorgas, January 18, 1920

div1.p: Carter discusses the benefits and disadvantages of accompanying Gorgas to an unnamed location.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William Crawford Gorgas, January 18, 1920
div1.opener:
Miscl
Y.F-
-------------
Tampa, Fla.,
January 18/20.
My Dear Doctor Gorgas:
div1.p:
1/ If I do not go with you I purpose to continue my present work,
in malaria etc. until in the spring--up to, at any rate, March 20th. and
possibly to June 20th.--and then take my waiting orders.

2/ If you want me to go with you, I will ask for waiting orders
now, or at least early enough so as to get them by the date you will
want me. It would, I think, need from 2 to 4 weeks for me to go be-
fore a board and have the matter of waiting orders fixed. Indeed, I
doubt if it can be done within 2 weeks.

On this account I would be glad to know, as soon as you can determine
it (a) whether you want me with you in the yellow fever work and (b) if
so, when, so that I may fix it so that I can go free-handed.

I do not wish to go into the yellow fever work unless I can be of
service in it. I mean I don't want to go simply for my own sake.

I have been doing fairly useful work (for the U. S.) in malaria and,
although I have about finished my immediate schedule, I judge that I
will find more of it to do, even when I am on waiting orders, if only
in an advisory capacity. If I don't I won't care much. I have very
nearly done my quota.

If, however, I can be of service to you in the yellow fever work, I
will be glad to go.
